details.subjectOf: St. Mary in the Valley of Jehosaphat, Palestine
Direct subject of the Holy See from 1092 then subjected to Messina by anti-pope Anacletus II from 1131-1139. Later placed under the archbishop of Monreale (Benedictine) by Lucius III in 1183.

details.subjectOf: St. Mary and the Twelve Apostles at Bagnara, Calabria

notes: Non molto distante da Francavilla su una grande piattaforma (denominata placa) sita in Contrada Badiazza, in una strada scoscesa e impervia si trova l'Abbazia di San Salvatore della Placa innalzata nel 1802 dal conte Ruggero su preghiera del monaco Cremete. Si sa ben poco della vita che i monaci conducevano all'interno dell'abbazia, essa venne abbandonata nel XVIII sec. dai basiliani perch�� situata in punto troppo scomodo

details.subjectOf: St. Bartholomew of Lipari/St. Savior of Patti

notes: This had been converted into a fortress by Charles V in the 1540s. The 12th-century moanstery was completely destroyed by the explosion of a powder magazine. After some time, the monks were relocated to a new location in 1573, a complex in the baroque style situated in the Charybdis neighborhood. [Is this the Greek monastery to which Abulafia, "Norman Kingdom of Africa," p. 29, refers when he writes "The Greek monastery of San Salvatore in Messina was permitted by the crown to send part of its wheat surplus to the hungry towns of north Africa, and not to a Christian destination, in order to obtain wax, probably for liturgical use.")

name.en: Saint Pantaleon of the Presbyter Scholarios

notes: It is difficult to date these remains. Maurici notes that their similarity to the Castello Lombardia may suggest a Swabian origin.
Minimal remains survive.

Minimal remains survive. Maurici notes that although it is likely that a castle may have existed in the twelfth century, it isn't until the fourteenth century that we have strong evidence of its existence.
Visible remains likely date from seventeenth century.
Exact location is not known. One possibility, according to Maurici, is that it was located on Monte Bonifato in the comune of Alcamo.
Some traces of a wall and a fully restored tower remain.
No visible remains exist.
Section of wall and a part of a vault survive.
Maurici states that the visible ruins surround and partially cover what is likely an earlier fourteenth-century structure.
Few remnants remain and the medieval structure was likely damaged significantly by the earthquake of 1693.
It is very difficult to identify the parts of the castle that are of Norman origin.
Maurici notes that the castle is fully underground; there are a few hints of the walls and aboveground is a tank loaded with stones (written in 1994).
According to Maurici, no elements can be dated to the Norman period with certainity.
It is possible that the only remaining section from the Norman period is the facade of the entrance tower.
Practically nothing survives and a large water tank now sits on the site.
Remains limited to a small number of wall remnants on the cliff overlooking Caltanissetta's cemetery.
Idrisi says this was located approximately 12 miles from Caltanissetta.

Maurici notes that surviving are some walls of a tower that is in ruins, traces of a wall and an entire wing of the south side that has been transformed over the centuries in response to housing demands.
There do not seem to be visible Norman remains.
Maurici observes that the visible structure was constructed on an earlier site before 1385 by Count Francesco Ventimiglia.
Maurici says that the castle was already in ruins in 1700 and was completely destroyed in the 19th century.
No Norman elements seem to be visible.
The asociation of this site, which is mentioned by Idrisi, with Castelbuono, is a guess by Maurici.
None of the visible building is datable to the Norman period.
Has been ompletely transformed and refaced.
None of the visible structure can be dated with confidence to the Norman period.
Parts of the outer wall survive as well as sections of internal structures, a tower and a cistern.
Limited sections of a wall survive.
Fell during the earthquake of 1693.
Was fully demolished before 1900.
Maurici believes that the outer wall that closed the entire upper flat space of the cliff is of Norman origin.
Only known from Idrisi, who places it near Corleone.
Was destroyed or damaged on the death of Frederick II and was reconstructed by Manfred.
The keep/fortified tower and the internal perimeter wall survive, though they have been profoundly altered.
Has been restored and profoundly altered.
Appears to have been completely refaced.
Only a small section of the restored walls survive.
Maurici notes that surviving are the remains of the perimeter wall, a cistern covered by a vault, and a castle chapel dedicated to St. Anne.
A water tank obscures the very scanty remains.
Was completely destroyed during the earthquake of 1693.
Not recorded in Maurici.
Maurici notes that excavations have not determined with certainty which structures date to the 11th and 12th centuries.
Not recorded in Maurici.
It has been partially reconstructed and is now used as a jail.

Small sections of the walls and a doorway survive. In August 2015, a rep. from the tourism office said that there is a section of a wall on via Gian Giacomo Adria, just before via Vittorio Veneto (behind the church and convent of St. Francis)
Well-restored remains.
All that remain are blocks of stone with Cufic inscriptions.
The main tower (based on a quadrangular plan) is probably from the Norman era.
Minimal remains exist on the highest point of the cliff.
Modest remains survive.
Significantly damaged by the 1693 earthquake; only remains of the (refaced) wall survive.

Was radically refaced in 1487 and transformed into a sumptuous residence. It became a jail in the 18th century and was in ruins by 1850 or so. What remains today are impressive ruins from the 1487 renovation.
Traces of external walls, a narrow internal wall and the base of a master tower (based on a rectangular plan) remain.
Signficantly damaged in the earthquake of 1693, a tower, a section of a rampart and a walled-in window survive.
No visible remains of the medieval structure survive.
Maurici notes that it stood high above the town and for all practical purposes has disappeared.
Maurici, writing in 1994, notes that part of it is used as a shelter for hikers.
Surviving structure does not date to the Norman age.
Little information about this fortification survives.
In complete ruins since at least the 18th century, nothing survives other than insignificant remains of the wall behind the Magistrates' Court.
The date of the surviving structures cannot be known with certainty.
Maurici believes the site was Monte Vaccara, outside of Nicosia.
Badly damaged during the earthquake of 1693, a tower and a section of wall have been restored.
Maurici observes that nothing of its medieval appearance is preserved on its exterior.
Location has been estimated.
Few remains survive.
Was profoundly altered in the 19th century and in 1922 was almost totally destroyed during the expansion of the port.
The castle was situated next to the archbishop's palace and was totally dstroyed as a result of successive expansions of the palace.
Was situated next to the archbishop's palace and was totally dstroyed as a result of successive expansions of the palace.
Construction of a water tank destroyed any surviving remains.
Maurici argues that although the exact location is not known with certainty, there is a possibility that it was located in "Piano Martino," quarter there there are ruins marked "Castello di Ruggero".
No part of these ruins can be dated with precision to the Norman period.
Few remains survive and they are difficult to make sense of.
Location has been estimated.
Few remains.
Maurici suggests that the visible structure may date to the 13th century.
It is impossible to date these ruins with precision.
Maurici notes that the castle was destroyed in the earthquake of 1693 and its stones were reused for the construction of the church and convent of the Riformati.
Dating the remains is problematic.
Norman structure has been replaced by the one you can see today, which dates from the 13th century.
Traces of a wall survive as well as an opening that may have been a doorway. The date of these is uncertain.
The remains that survive are in a terrible state.
A guess is that it may have been located on the site of Palazzo Cutò, which was terribly damaged during the earthquake of 1968.
Structure has been reworked over the centuries and it is difficult to distinguish the Norman remains from the later additions.
Visible structure is modern.

variations: Visible remains likely date to the 14th century.

notes: Maurici notes that the church is the only structure that dates to the Norman era.
Maurici believes that this was likely located near the canal that connects the Ortygia to the mainland.
Visible remains cannot be dated to the Norman period with certainty.
Transformed, it was destroyed in the 19th century and on the summit (Rocca di Termini Alta) is now a water tank. According to Maurici, some pieces of the wall remain.
Judging from the style, the visible structure may date from Frederick II's time or later.
Surviving ruins cannot be dated with certainty.
Scanty remains from a wall and a tower postdate the Norman period.
Was damaged by the earthquake of 1693; the "castle" is actually a few remains partially surrounded by more recent walls.
Maurici suggests Gangi as a possible location.
Maurici notes that it was possibly located at Santo Stefano Vecchio. The community was moved because of a landslide, initiating the development of Santo Stefano di Camastra.
Location can not be identified with certainty, other than it was located in the Val Demone.
SEE MAURICI FOR MORE INFORMATION

Work on the structure appears to have been done by Ingegnere Francesco Ciriminna before his death in 2011. His son, Dario Ciriminna, holds the unpublished research. Also, I was pointed to the popular travel book, _Il Libro dell' isola di Pantelleria_, by Angelo D'Aietti. Told also that Katia Lionti, wife of the architect Fatini, may have done some work at the foundation level of the castle.
